document.docTitle: A phenylpropanoid diglyceride associates with the leaf rust resistance Lr34res gene in wheat

paragraph.docTitle: A phenylpropanoid diglyceride associates with the leaf rust resistance Lr34res gene in wheat

subSection.paragraph:
Nandhakishore Rajagopalan a , Yuping Lu a , Ian W. Burton b , Fanny Monteil-Rivera c , Annamaria Halasz d , Elsa Reimer e , Rebecca Tweidt f , Anita Brûl � e-Babel g , Hadley R. Kutcher f , Frank M. You h , Sylvie Cloutier h , Miroslava Cuperlovic-Culf i , Colin W. Hiebert e , Brent D. McCallum e
, Michele C . Loewen
j, *

subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO

document.paragraph:
The gene Lr34res is one of the most long-lasting sources of quantitative fungal resistance in wheat. It is shown to be effective against leaf, stem, and stripe rusts, as well as powdery mildew and spot blotch. Recent biochemical characterizations of the encoded ABC transporter have outlined a number of allocrites, including phospholipids and abscisic acid, consistent with the established general promiscuity of ABC transporters, but ultimately leaving its mechanism of rust resistance unclear. Working with flag leaves of
Triticum aestivum
L. variety ‘Thatcher’ (Tc) and a near-isogenic line of ‘Thatcher’ into which the Lr34res allele was introgressed (Tc þLr34res ; RL6058), a comparative semi-targeted metabolomics analysis of flavonoid-rich extracts revealed virtually identical profiles with the exception of one metabolite accumulating in Tc þLr34res , which was not present at comparable levels in Tc. Structural characterization of the purified metabolite revealed a phenylpropanoid diglyceride structure, 1- O - p -coumaroyl-3- O -feruloylglycerol ( CFG ). Additional profiling of CFG across a collection of near-isogenic lines and representative Lr34 haplotypes highlighted a broad association between the presence of Lr34res and elevated accumulations of CFG . Depletion of CFG upon infection, juxtaposed to its relatively lower anti-fungal activity, suggests CFG may serve as a storage form of the more potent anti-microbial hydroxycinnamic acids that are accessed during defense responses. Altogether these findings suggest a role for the encoded LR34res ABC transporter in modifying the accumulation of CFG , leading to increased accumulation of anti-fungal metabolites, essentially priming the wheat plant for defense.

subSection.paragraph: As a result of their sessile nature, plants are exposed to an array of environmental stressors ranging from abiotic pressures such as salt, cold, heavy metal and heat, to biotic threats including nematodes and insects, as well as viral, bacterial and fungal pathogens. To address this, plants have developed complex networks of molecular and biochemical mechanisms to detect different stressors and defend itself against them.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. National Research Council of Canada , 100 Sussex Drive, Ottawa, OA, K1 A 0R6, Canada . E-mail address: michele.loewen@nrc.ca (M. C . Loewen).

subSection.paragraph:
In contrast to this, alleles of a number of genetic loci have been correlated with more durable, albeit quantitative, adult-plant resistance (APR) against fungal pathogens in particular. One of the best characterized of these is Lr34, with evaluation of breeding lines suggesting its effectiveness has been lasting for more than 100 years ( Dyck et al., 1966 ). This same Lr3 4 has most notably been effective against cereal rusts including leaf, stem, and stripe rusts (caused by
Puccinia triticina
,
P. graminis
, and
P. striiformis
, respectively), as well as powdery mildew and to a lesser extent spot blotch, the latter two caused by
Blumeria graminis
and
Bipolaris sorokiniana ,
respectively ( Dyck, 1993 ; Spielmeyer et al., 2005 ; Lillemo et al., 2013 ). The gene responsible for Lr34 resistance was cloned and found to encode an ATP binding cassette (ABC) transporter ( Krattinger et al., 2009 ), with susceptible-associated ( Lr34sus ) and resistance-associated ( Lr34res ) alleles. These alleles are differentiated by a 3-nucleotide indel, resulting in deletion of a phenylalanine from the LR34Res protein that occurs at position 546 in the LR34Sus protein, and another single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) converting a tyrosine at LR34Res position 634 to a histidine. Dakouri et al. (2010) identified additional polymorphisms within Lr34 : an A /T SNP in the fourth intron and a 1-nucleotide indel in the tenth exon causing a frameshift. Determination of the four Lr34 polymorphic positions in 653 wheat accessions defined four haplotypes, but only one of which was defined as the Lr34res allele, conferring the Lr34 resistance phenotype. The presence of Lr34res has been suggested to yield constitutive defense responses in the absence of pathogen ( Chauhan et al., 2015 ; Krattinger et al., 2019 ), including expression of genes linked to antimicrobial activity (proteases/chitinases), as well as constitutive expression of abscisic acid (ABA) -inducible responses ( Hulbert et al., 2007 ; Krattinger et al., 2019 ).

To gain further insight into the nature of potential wheat Lr34res - associated metabolites, a comparative semi-targeted metabolomics profiling strategy was implemented. Based on previous reports suggesting an association between Lr34res and constitutive defense responses ( Hulbert et al., 2007 ; Chauhan et al., 2015 ), a particular focus on the defense associated polyphenolic flavonoid family of metabolites was maintained. Working from the flag leaves of
Triticum aestivum
L. ( Poaceae ) variety ‘Thatcher’ (Tc) and the near-isogenic line (NIL) of ‘Thatcher’ into which the Lr34res allele was introgressed (Tc þLr34res ; RL6058), outcomes of a comparative liquid chromatography/mass spectroscopy (LC/MS) analysis of flavonoid rich extracts are described, with an identified target structure validated by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and high resolution mass spectroscopy (HRMS). Additional screening of Lr34res lines in the presence and absence of pathogen, compared to Lr34sus lines, as well as the anti-fungal activity of the target and its associated metabolites, validated original outcomes and highlighted depletion of the target upon infection. Together these findings emphasize a possible role for Lr34res in mediating rust resistance by enabling higher accumulation of anti-fungal phenylproponoid metabolites.

heading.emphasis: 2.1. Profiling of phenolics in the flag leaves of RL6058 (TcþLr34res NIL)

subSection.paragraph:
A comparative semi-targeted metabolomics profiling strategy was implemented, with a particular focus on the polyphenolic, flavonoid spectrum of metabolites. Plants were grown in growth chambers and flag leaves harvested post-anthesis, as the anthers were turning white (BBCH69 ( Lancashire et al., 1991 );). Working from the flag leaves of
T. aestivum
variety ‘Thatcher’ (Tc) and the ‘Thatcher’ NIL RL6058 (Tc þ Lr34res), a comparative liquid chromatography/mass spectroscopic (LC/MS) analysis of flavonoid rich extracts revealed highly similar, albeit not identical, profiles ( Fig. 1 ). Proposed assignments for most of the detected peaks were tabulated based on retention time, UV-spectrophotometric λ max , and mass spectrometric m/z values, compared to literature values ( Table 1 ). In addition to the assigned flavonoid peaks, two major peaks were detected that could not be assigned and were named P1 and P2, respectively. Interestingly, the only difference detected between the profiles arising from the two wheat lines was at P2, which accumulated in RL6058, but was not present at comparable levels in Tc ( Fig. 1 inset).

emphasis.heading: 2.2. Structural characterization of the P2 metabolite from RL6058
(TcþLr34res NIL)

subSection.paragraph:
Several milligrams of the P2 metabolite were collected from RL6058 flag leaves and concentrated to enable structural characterization. LC-UV analysis of the enriched metabolite yielded a major peak at 20.8 min (Supplemental Fig. S1A ), with the general spectral profile indicating a major band at 315 nm (Supplemental Fig. S1B ). LC/HRMS was conducted in the positive mode on the enriched sample. The high resolution mass spectrum ( Fig. 2A ) of the major peak at 21.1 min (corresponding to 20.8 min in the UV chromatogram (Supplemental Fig. S1A )) showed a presumed protonated molecular mass ion [M þ H]
þ
at m/z 415.1374 ( m/ z calc. 415.1387, mass error 3.2 ppm) and a sodium adduct [M þ Na]
þ
at m/z 437.1202 ( m/z calc. 437.1207, mass error 1.2 ppm) corresponding to a putative parent compound of chemical formula C 22 H 22 O 8 ( Fig. 2B ). The fragment at m/z 397.1276 suggests the loss of a molecule of water. Two other fragments at m/z 177.0585 and 147.0488 matching the formulae C 10 H 9 O 3 ( m/z calc. 177.0546, mass error 22.1 ppm) and C 9 H 7 O 2 ( m/z calc.147.0441, mass error 32.0 ppm) were also observed, consistent with the predicted presence of the feruloyl and coumaroyl moieties, respectively, in the molecule.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. LC-UV profile of phenolic compounds detected in an extract from RL6058 (Tc þLr34res NIL) flag leaves. Metabolites in the flag leaf extract were separated and characterized by LC/MS. Numbers identify peaks for which flavonoid metabolite identities are assigned based on retention time, UV-λmax and mol wt in Table 1. P1 and P2 refer to nonflavonoid compounds of unknown identity. Absorbance values represent adjusted values across the entire scanned range (210–600 nm). Inset) Comparison of the elution region from 23 to 27 min for Tc þLr34res and Tc emphasizing the reduced accumulation of the compound denoted as P2 in the Tc extract, compared to the Tc þLr34res extract.
Peak assignments for flavonoids detected in Tc and TcþLr34res flag leaves by LC/MS.

tableNote.paragraph: (1) Estiarte et al., (1999); (2) Olenichenko et al., (2006); (3) Ioset et al., (2007); (4) Harder and Christensen (2000) ; (5) Ko et al., (1998); (6) Kumazawa et al., (2000); (7) Ramarathnam et al., (1989); (8) Deng et al., (2008); (9) Cai et al., (2005).
a No. refers to the peak number as indicated in the chromatogram shown in Fig. 1. Assignments were completed based on.

subSection.paragraph: 1D 1 H NMR spectra acquired from the enriched sample indicated 19 observable protons in methanol solution (Supplementary Fig. S2A ). The 13 C spectrum gave a carbon count of 22 with the NOE-suppressed spectrum showing 2 carbon resonances with twice the area of surrounding resonances. This confirmed the molecular formula C 22 H 22 O 8 proposed from the exact mass measurement reported above. The doubling of many of the integrated intensities in the aromatic/vinyl region indicated a high degree of symmetry in the molecule. Carbon peaks at around 169 ppm (Supplementary Fig. S2B ) indicated 2 carbonyl oxygens. Carbon peaks at around 161 ppm and 150 ppm indicated 2 phenol groups, with the carbon peak at around 69 ppm indicating a methoxyl group. Analysis of the multiplicity edited HSQC spectrum, showing directly bonded H– C ( Fig. 3 ), as well as an HMBC (Supplemental Fig. S3 ) providing correlations between carbons and protons that were separated by two, three, and sometimes in conjugated systems, four bonds were used for spin systems assignment. The HSQC showed 15 protonated carbons including 1 x CH 3 , 2 x CH 2 and the rest CH . The chemical shift of the two equivalent CH 2 groups and the CH at 4.28 and 4.15 ppm are typical for a sn-1,3 di-ester-substituted glycerol. This was confirmed from the HMBC correlations from 4.28 ppm to 169 ppm. HMBC correlations from the carbonyl carbon into the vinyl protons and then from vinyl carbons into the aromatic systems supported a dicinnamate type of substituted glycerol. The C 2 spin systems in the aromatic region supported a p -coumaroyl group on the glycerol. This was further supported by the HMBC correlations in the aromatic region. The correlation between the methyl protons at 3.87 ppm and the aromatic carbon at 114 ppm identified one of the groups as a feruloyl group. A final assignment of carbon resonances, as well as a list of related proton resonances was compiled ( Table 2 ) and presented on the proposed structure ( Fig. 3 ). This assignment agreed well with 13 C data previously reported for similar diglyceride metabolites characterized by NMR ( Cooper et al., 1978 ; Xiong et al., 2009 ). The overall proposed structure was that of 1- O-p -coumaroyl-3- O -feruloylglycerol ( CFG ), a phenylpropanoid diglyceride reported in other plant extracts ( Cooper et al., 1978 ; Delaporte et al., 2006 ; Ma et al., 2007 ; Xiong et al., 2009 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Structure elucidation by HRMS analysis of the enriched P2 metabolite obtained from RL6058 (Tc þLr34res NIL) flag leaves. A) HRMS spectrum of the P2 sample isolated from RL6058 flag leaves. B) Predicted putative C 22 H 22 O 8 structure with proposed fragmentation pattern matching the derived product ion spectra in the HRMS spectrum.

Fig. 3. Structure validation of P2 metabolite isolated from the RL6058 (Tc þLr34res NIL) flag leaves. A) Multiplicity edited HSQC spectrum arising from the P2 sample, including resonance assignments according to the proposed structure, shown below, with full assignments included in Table 2. B) The annotated structure of metabolite 1- O -p-Coumaroyl-3- O -feruloylglycerol (CFG) is included below.

subSection.paragraph: The structure was validated by independent synthesis (SynInnova) of the proposed compound, with NMR analysis of the synthesized product matching that obtained from the flag leaf metabolite (data not shown).

emphasis.heading: 2.3. Higher accumulations of CFG correlate with the presence of Lr34res,
but not Lr22a or Lr67res, and are depleted upon infection with leaf rust

subSection.paragraph:
Subsequently, the accumulation of CFG in Tc versus RL6058 lines in the presence and absence of infection by
Puccinia triticina
isolate TDBG (11-180-1) was quantified. Plants were grown in growth chambers and inoculated with urediniospores at BBCH-61, with flag leaves sampled at time zero, and then once a week for 3.5 weeks (at 7, 14 and 24 days post inoculation (dpi)). The average detected accumulations of CFG highlighted a lack of any significant interactions for the two lines tested with respect to infection condition or sample time (dpi), but a significant difference ( p -value ¼ 0.0225) with respect to the observed increased accumulation of CFG for RL6058 compared to Tc as an average of all samples in the experiment ( Fig. 4A ; Supplemental Fig. S4 ). In contrast, accumulations of CFG for Tc þLr22a or Tc þLr67res NILs were not found to be significant ( p -values ¼ 0.1965 and 0.9332 respectively) across all conditions compared to Tc ( Fig. 4B and C ; Supplemental Fig. S4 ). Together these findings are consistent with the preliminary finding ( Fig. 1 ) and support the correlation of the presence of Lr34res with accumulation of CFG .

Unexpectedly, the data also revealed that the presence of the pathogen caused CFG levels to plummet. This was found to hold true for all lines tested (including Tc, Tc þLr34res , Tc þLr22a and Tc þLr67res ) at seven dpi, and that levels remained low to the final time point at 24 dpi ( Fig. 4 ). The average detected accumulations of CFG highlighted an interaction for each of the wheat lines tested with respect to sample time (dpi) which is expected ( p -values ¼ 2.3e- 04, 2.6e- 03 and 7.3e- 04 respectively for Tc þLr34res , Tc þLr22a and Tc þLr67res ), and significant differences ( p -values ¼ 2.43e- 08, 5.62e- 07 and 3.05e- 06 respectively for Tc þLr34res , Tc þLr22a and Tc þLr67res ) with respect to the observed increased accumulation of CFG compared to Tc across all conditions (Supplemental Fig. S4 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. CFG accumulations are greater in RL6058 (Tc þLr34res NIL) in wheat flag leaves compared to Tc, and are depleted by infection with the rust pathogen. Accumulation of CFG in Thatcher and A) RL6058 (Tc þLr34res ), B) Tc þLr22a and C) Tc þLr67res flag leaves over time, in the presence and absence of
P. triticina
isolate. Error bars represent the standard error of the mean (n ¼ 4) of the average % TIC. Bars represent Tc (grey), RL6058 or Tc þLr22 or Tc þLr67 NILs as indicated (black), Tc with
P. triticina
infection (large spots), RL6058 or Tc þ Lr33 or Tc þ Lr67 NILs (as indicated) with
P. triticina
infection (small spots). The significance of differences were determined by multifactor ANOVA with details tabulated in Supplemental Fig. S4.
Proton and carbon resonances arising from the purified P2 metabolite.

emphasis.heading: 2.4. Higher accumulations of CFG correlate with the presence of Lr34res
more broadly

subSection.paragraph:
To more generally assess the association between the accumulation of CFG and the presence of the Lr34res allele, the study was expanded to include quantitative profiling of CFG across an array of Lr34 haplotype wheat accessions ( Dakouri et al., 2014 ). Twenty-two accessions ( Table 3 ) representing the five
major Lr
34 haplotypes, where haplotype 1 corresponds to the Lr34res allele, were grown in growth chambers and flag leaves harvested post-anthesis when the anthers were extruded (BBCH69). Following metabolite extraction, CFG was quantified by LC/MS analysis with outcomes showing that the median average % total ion count (TIC) value for haplotype 1 ranged from two to five times higher than the medians for haplotypes 2–5 ( Fig. 5A ). While the data was not found to be significant (Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric) analysis yielded a p -value of 0.09), the trend is consistent with observations for the Tc þLr34res NIL. Furthermore, when the study was expanded to include a selection of winter wheat lines (that do not contain the Lr34res allele) with mixed rust resistance phenotypes (see methods and materials for details), no CFG was detected for any cultivar (data not shown).

Finally, we evaluated the accumulation of CFG in the flag leaves of five pairs of Sumai sibling lines (sibs) and both parental lines, with each pair of sibs consisting of
Lr 34þ
and Lr34- counterparts validated by phenotypic assessment of leaf rust infection levels and resistance phenotype ( Table 4 ). These were grown in the field, infected with leaf rust and harvested at maximum severity before senescence, while leaves were still green. Infected
Lr 34þ
Sumai lines (and the ‘Sumai 3’ parent) accumulated five-fold more CFG than their Lr34- counterparts or the Tc parent ( Fig. 5B ), again consistent with relative accumulations observed in Tc þLr34res containing haplotype 1 plants in growth chambers ( Fig. 5A ). Further analysis emphasized that this relative difference between Sumai sibs was unique to CFG , compared to other flavonoids in the original profile (for example Fig. 5C ).

heading.emphasis: 2.5. Anti-fungal activity of CFG and related compounds

subSection.paragraph:
To understand the potential role of CFG during infection, initially, the ability of CFG to inhibit urediniospore germination was evaluated in vitro . Isolates of presentative
P. triticina
and
P. striiformis
were grown in the presence of CFG , MeOH (control) or water (control), and the number of urediniospores germinated after 24 h were tabulated. The presence of CFG significantly reduced
P. triticina
urediniospore germination by ~20% (p> 0.01) compared to control levels ( Fig. 6A ), while the MeOH solvent control had no effect compared to water. Albeit not as potent, similar observations were made in the independent experiment with
P. striiformis
, where CFG elicited a significant 8% (p <0.05) reduction in urediniospore germination rates ( Fig. 6B ).

The possibility that CFG , as well as its break down products ( Fig. 7A ), might have growth inhibitory activity against this causative agent of Fusarium head blight, was also tested. Consistent with a prior report ( Cuperlovic-Culf et al., 2016 ), ferulic acid (FA) maintained strong inhibitory activity against the growth of
F. graminearum
( Fig. 7B ), reducing colony diameters by ~ 80–90% compared to the control, across all three time points evaluated. Interestingly, coumaric acid ( CA ), feruloyl glycerol ( FG ) and CFG all showed similar levels of significant reduction in fungal growth compared to the control (~65–70% compared to the control by day 3); however, their inhibitory effects were all weaker than FA. From a phenotypic perspective, it is also notable that colonies treated with CA and FA were distinctly circular and smooth, compared to those treated with FG and CFG , which were more highly filamentous ( Fig. 7C ).

To understand the effect of Lr34res on plant metabolism, a semi-targeted metabolite profiling study was undertaken, based on a comparison of the (poly)phenolic/flavonoid families of metabolites in two NILs of wheat, Tc and Tc þLr34res . This area of specialized metabolism was targeted based on documented roles for many of these types of compounds in plant defense responses against various external stresses, including fungal pathogens (reviewed in Kushalappa et al., 2016 ; Tohge et al., 2018 ; Zaynab et al., 2018 ). Interestingly, in the absence of pathogens, these NILs had virtually identical polyphenolic/flavonoid profiles, with the exception of the observed higher accumulation of the phenylpropanoid diglyceride, CFG , in the Lr34res line ( Fig. 1 ).

Phenylpropanoid diglycerides were first identified in what is considered to be a wild relative of cultivated wheat,
Aegilops ovata ( Cooper et al., 1978 )
. CFG in particular has been characterized across an array of other plants including,
Tillandsia streptocarpa
, a South American herbaceous epiphyte with established natural anti-inflammatory activity ( Delaporte et al., 2006 ),
Ananas comosus
a popular tropical fruit ( Ma et al., 2007 ) and
Sparganium stoloniferum
, widely distributed in China with anti-tumor activities ( Xiong et al., 2009 ). Phenylpropanoid diglycerides have been further identified in extracts from propolis, a product made by bees from plant exudates used in hive building, with documented antibacterial properties as well as putative antitumoral, antioxidative and immunomodulatory activities (reviewed in Isidorov et al., 2014 ). The bioactivity of phenylpropanoid diglycerides has been patented ( Lowe and Bryant, 2014 ) and some aspects of their biosynthesis elucidated ( Tsuchiyama et al., 2007 ). Interestingly, their overall structure is reminiscent of another well documented anti-microbial/anti-tumoral metabolite, curcumin ( Moghadamtousi et al., 2014 ). Thus, Lr34res -associated increases in the accumulation of CFG is entirely consistent with Lr34res -associated resistance against multiple microbial pathogens ( Dyck, 1993 ; Spielmeyer et al., 2005 ; Lillemo et al., 2013 ).

caption.paragraph: Leaf rust infection for Sumai sibling lines used in this study.

tr.th: Average leaf rust flag leaf severity a (%) (n ¼ 3)

paragraph.tableNote: a The average proportion (%) of the flag leaf area infected with leaf rust as estimated using the modified Cobb scale ( Peterson et al., 1948 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Higher accumulation of CFG in flag leaves correlates with the presence of the Lr34res allele. A) Accumulation of CFG in Lr34 haplotypes. Twenty-two lines (Table 3) were assessed across the five haplotype groups with 5 lines tested for each of haplotypes 1–4 and 2 lines tested for haplotype 5. The median, quartiles and range of % total ion count (TIC) for the LC/MS peak corresponding to 1- O -p -Coumaroyl-3- O -feruloylglycerol (CFG) for each line (n ¼ 4) is represented, grouped by haplotype. A Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric) analysis yielded a p -value of 0.09091. B) Accumulation of CFG in the flag leaves of five Sumai sib-pairs, grown in the field, and their two parent line ‘Sumai 3’ and ‘Thatcher’ (Table 4). Each point represents the value obtained from a different line (n ¼ 1 for each line) and an independent biological replicate, with the indicated p -value calculated by one-way ANOVA. C) Change in relative accumulations of metabolites in the Sumai Lr34þ sibs versus the Sumai Lr34- sibs, and their respective parents, grown in the fields, with Peak #’s referring to metabolites identified in Fig. 1 and Table 1. Each point represents the value obtained from a different line (n ¼ 1 for each line) and an independent biological replicate, with the significance of differences at 5% probability level determined by one-way ANOVA with LSD test post hoc. Treatments with the same letter are not significantly different.

subSection.paragraph:
The relevance of the anti-microbial activity of CFG was specifically validated for fungal pathogens in vitro ( Figs. 6 and 7 ). While the potency of CFG was comparable to those of potential breakdown products FG and CA , it was significantly lower than FA. This is consistent with an earlier study in which FA was one of the most potent anti-fungal compounds against
F. graminaearum
across an array of tested inhibitors ( Cuperlovic-Culf et al., 2016 ). That a smaller specialized metabolite (FA), of which CFG is in part comprised, has higher potency than CFG itself, raises the hypothetical possibility of CFG being a storage form of potent antifungal hydroxycinnamic acids (HCAs). This idea would be consistent with the observed depletion of CFG upon infection with rust regardless of Lr34res ( Fig. 4 ). While another explanation for depletion could be degradation as an energy source to address the high energy cost of defense ( Bolton et al., 2008 ), noted pathogen-induced induction of phenylpropanoid biosynthetic genes in a TcþLr34res line ( Bolton et al., 2008 ), raises the question ‘why would a plant deplete CFG for energy, while expending energy to make more of the same HCA’ s?’. Finally, these findings are consistent with other recent studies on FHB resistant quantitative trait loci (QTL), including Fhb2 and a second gene referred to as 2DL , that have been linked to accumulation of HCA-amides and other flavonoid-glycosides ( Kage et al., 2017a , b; Karre et al., 2017 ; Dhokane et al., 2016 ; Karre et al., 2019 ).

Importantly, the association of increased CFG levels with Lr34res was validated in a quantitative study that showed significantly higher accumulation of CFG in Tc þLr34res compared to Tc, an effect that was not detected in either Tc þLr22a or Tc þLr67res compared to Tc ( Fig. 4 ). The correlation between Lr34res and increased accumulation of CFG was also observed in
Lr 34þ
Sumai lines compared to their LR34- counterparts, even when grown in the field ( Fig. 5B ). Finally, although not deemed statistically significant, the Lr34res containing haplotype 1 accessions yielded a 2–5 fold higher mean CFG accumulation value compared to the susceptible haplotypes ( Fig. 5A ). Also consistent with this was the absence of CFG in winter wheat accessions that lack Lr34res . Thus the shear breadth of lines for which this hypothesis holds true argues against the possibility of the increased CFG levels arising from any unlinked genes; although, these outcomes do not go as far as to discriminate between the possibilities of a direct effect of Lr34res functionality versus an Lr34res -linkage effect.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 6. Effect of CFG treatment on urediniospore germination in vitro . Urediniospores were plated on agar containing CFG, MeOH or water and the number of germinated urediniospores counted after 24 h incubation and compared to the total number plated. A) leaf rust
Puccinia triticina
race isolate MBDS ; B) stripe rust
Puccinia striiformis
f.sp.
tritici
isolate C-PST-5. For both experiments, error bars represent the standard deviation of 4–5 replicates. Significance of differences was determined by oneway ANOVA with LSD. test post hoc at 5% probability level. Treatments with the same letter are not significantly different.

Fig. 7. Effect of CFG treatment on colony growth of the causative agent of wheat Fusarium head blight,
Fusarium graminearum
. A) Structures tested for anti-fungal activity CFG; 1-O-feruloylglycerol (FG); coumaric acid (CA); ferulic acid (FA). B) Radial growth of a single plug of
F. graminearum
on PDA plates containing 4 mM of the indicated compound or DMSO (Ctrl). Each point represents the average and standard deviation of four replicates. Error bars indicate the significant difference (n ¼ 4) with p values calculated compared to the CFG by Student’ s t -test demarked as * p <0.02, ** p <0.0002, *** p <0.000002. C) Representative images of
F. graminearum
colonies after 3 days of growth on PDA plates with DMSO (Ctrl) or 4 mM of compounds.

subSection.paragraph:
This work highlights an association between the presence of Lr34res and elevated accumulation of the phenylpropanoid diglyceride CFG across an array of Lr34res containing wheat lines, with the expected partial anti-fungal activity of CFG validated against both
Puccinia
and
Fusarium
fungal pathogens. Its lower potency compared to individual HCAs of which it is composed, along with its observed depletion upon fungal infection, raise the new (to be tested) hypothesis of CFG serving as a storage form of HCAs that the plant accesses during defense responses. A review of the current literature highlights a number of possible functional roles for the LR34res ABC transporter in eliciting the accumulation of CFG .These include i) direct transport of CFG and/or the related HCA precursors/breakdown metabolites; ii) inhibition of the transport of these same metabolites; or iii) indirect modulation of the biosynthesis of these metabolites by signaling effects elicited by known allocrites of LR34res ( Deppe et al., 2018 ; Krattinger et al., 2019 ). Ongoing work includes a transcriptomic analysis of the Tc and Tc þLr34res wheat in the presence and absence of leaf rust infection to shed additional light on the status of HCA, phenylpropanoid and flavonoid biosynthesis pathways in Lr34res wheat, as well as associations between these observations and LR34’s recently demonstrated ABA and lipid transport functionalities.

1- O-p -coumaroyl-3- O -feruloylglycerol ( CFG ; Cat # SL-1122) and feruloyl glycerol ( FG ; Cat # SL-1121) were synthesized by SynInnova Laboratories Inc. Ferulic acid (FA) and coumaric acid ( CA ) were purchased from Sigma. All other chemicals were obtained from Millipore Sigma (Oakville, Canada ), unless otherwise noted below.

heading.emphasis: 5.2. Plant growth, fungal infection and flag leaf harvest conditions

paragraph.emphasis:
5.2.1. Varieties of Triticum aestivum L. ( Poaceae ) Thatcher,
ThatcherþLr34res (RL6058), ThatcherþLr22a and ThatcherþLr67res NIL experiments

subSection.paragraph:
Thatcher (Thatcher Control; Lr34sus ; Tc) and the NILs RL6058 (Tc þLr34res NIL), Tc þLr22a and Tc þLr67res were developed by the late Peter Dyck (Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada Cereal Research Centre, former Cereal Research Center, Winnipeg, Manitoba , Canada ). Plants were grown in Sunshine Mix # 8 (75% sphagnum peat moss, 20% perlite and 5% vermiculite (Sungro Horticulture, Agawam, MA, USA ), in growth cabinets with a 16 h light phase at 22
�
C , and 8 h dark phase at 17
�
C . In the case where rust infection was applied in growth chambers, plants were inoculated with
Puccinia triticina
race TDBG (11-180-1) urediniospores, at the beginning of anthesis (BBCH-61 ( Lancashire et al., 1991 )). Briefly, urediniospores harvested and stored at 80
�
C were heat-shocked at 42
�
C for 5 min and stored overnight at 4
�
C . A 10 mg /mL urediniospore suspension in mineral oil (Bayol; VWR) was prepared and used as the inoculum. The inoculum was placed into a gel capsule, connected to an air assisted spray manifold and target tissues were sprayed until an even oil film was observed over the area. The plants were kept at room temperature for an hour until the oil film disappeared and then transferred to a dark dew chamber for 24 h and then to a regular growth chamber, with the light and temperature settings as described above. For consistency across experiments, the flag leaves were collected post-anthesis, i.e. when the spike was at maturity with anthers turning white (BBCH-69). Flag leaves were cut, immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at 80
�
C . For each line tested, four biological replicates, with a minimum of 3–4 flag leaves being harvested from 3 individual plants per biological replicate, hence a total of 12–16 flag leaves from 12 plants per line profiled. For experiments where plants were inoculated with the pathogen (and controls for these experiments), flag leaves were sampled at infection time zero (BBCH-61), and once a week for 3.5 weeks.

Accessions used herein to represent the five Lr34 haplotypes were selected from the collections previously described ( Dakouri et al., 2014 ) and are listed in Table 3 . Plants in individual peat pots, were grown in growth cabinets with a 20 h light phase at 20
�
C , and 4 h dark phase at 15
�
C . Flag leaves were harvested as described above.

Winter wheat lines tested included cultivars ‘Emerson’ ( Graf et al., 2013a ; moderately rust resistant), ‘Gateway’ ( Graf et al., 2013b ; moderate to good rust resistance), ‘32*17’ (pedigree Sumai 3 x McClintock; moderately susceptible to rust), ‘W522’ (pedigree: CDC Falcon x DH99W19 C *04; good rust resistance), ‘W520’ (pedigree: DH99W22 A *13/CDC Falcon; good rust resistance) and W538 (pedigree: DH99W18I*45 x CDC Ptarmigan; good rust resistance). Plants in individual Sunshine Mix # 4 pots were grown in growth cabinets with 16 h light, and 8 h dark photoperiod, at 22
�
C day and 17
�
C night, for three weeks, then vernalized at 4
�
C for 8 weeks, and then returned to the above chamber conditions. Flag leaves were harvested as described above.

The pedigree of the Sumai BC 5 F 1 population is Sumai 3*5// Thatcher/Sumai 3 ( Lr34res carrier). During each cycle of backcrossing to Sumai 3, only progenies heterozygous for Lr34 according to the DNA marker csLV34 (Lagudah et al., 2006) were crossed. BC 5 F 1 lines were selfed and homozygous resistant (
Lr 34þ
) and homozygous susceptible ( Lr34 -) BC 5 F 2 progeny were selected using the csLV34 marker. The selected progenies were selfed to generate five BC 5 F 3 sibling pairs of Sumai lines, each pair with one line being Lr34res homozygous and the other Lr34sus homozygous. The five Sumai sib pairs used in this study are indicated in Table 4 . These, along with the 2 parent lines, were seeded in field nurseries in approximately 1 m single rows with three replicates. Rows of susceptible rust spreader lines (mixtures of
T. aestivum
varieties 55% ‘Morocco’ 55%, 35% Thatcher, 10% Wolfe Barley) in these nurseries were inoculated with the leaf rust fungus (
Puccinia triticina
) using a mixture of virulence phenotypes representative of the population in Canada , allowing the test lines to become inoculated from the urediniospores that developed on the spreader rows. Flag leaves were sampled towards maturity when they were infected with leaf rust, generally post-anthesis (BBCH-69), by collecting the leaves onto ice in the field and then freezing them at 80
�
C within 30 min. Infection levels were rated and included in Table 4 .

heading.emphasis: 5.3. Extraction and metabolite profiling by LC-UV/MS

subSection.paragraph:
For all flag leaves profiled in this study, freeze-dried flag leaf tissue arising from each sampled condition ( 40 mg ) was crushed under liquid nitrogen and extracted into 1.5 mL 70% methanol/water with 10 min water bath sonication, then centrifuged at 9300 �g for 5 min. The supernatant was run through a Sep-Pak Vac 1 cc ( 100 mg ) tC18 Cartridge (Waters 036820), then eluent was collected and applied to analysis. A Waters Alliance 2695 chromatography system with in-line degasser, coupled to a 2996 Photodiode Array Detector and a ZQ 2000 Micromass detector were used to conduct sample analysis. MassLynx V4.0 was used for data acquisition and manipulation. A Waters Xbridge C 18, 3.5 μm, 150 � 2.10 mm column was used for the HPLC, with the column maintained at 35
�
C . A total of 5 μL of each sample was injected into the instrument. The photodiode array data acquisition included scanning from 210 to 600 nm , under the following solvent conditions: 0.06% acetic acid in 10% acetonitrile with 90% water (Solvent A ) and 0.06% acetic acid in 100% acetonitrile (Solvent B), with the gradient started at 100% Solvent A at 0.18 mL/min flow, going to 60% Solvent B over 40 min at 0.22 mL/min, followed by flushing the column with 100% B at 0.25 mL/min, prior to equilibration for the next injection. The mass spectroscopy (MS) was run under ES negative mode, and was scanned from 100 to 1200 Da. Cone voltages were set at 30–60 V with the source temperature set at 120
�
C , and de-solvation temperature set at 300
�
C .

Fresh Tc-Lr34 flag leaf tissue ( 270 g ) was crushed under liquid nitrogen and extracted with 600 mL 70% methanol/water with 10 min water bath sonication and then filtered through filter paper. The filtrate was concentrated using a 10 g C-18 cartridge (WAT043345), which also eliminated chlorophyll and carotene and other metabolites, because they passed through the filter, leaving the metabolites behind. Water was added to dilute the enriched metabolite samples to 10% methanol/ water, which was then concentrated again. The enriched metabolite fraction was then fractionated sequentially into 25 mL volumes of 20%, 30%, 40%, 50%, 60%, 70% and 100% methanol. The target metabolite (P2) located in the 70% methanol/water fraction was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC using a Phenomenex Gemini-NX 5 μm C 18, 250 � 10 mm column, with Solvent C : 100% water, Solvent D: 100% acetonitrile. The column was maintained at 30
�
C , and the pump holding at 66% Solvent C /34% Solvent D for 20 min at a flow rate of 3.0 mL/ min, then changing to 5% Solvent C with 95% Solvent D at 21 min for an additional 28 min. The data was collected using a DAD detector channel at 316 nm , from 13 min to 22 min with the trigger mode set to peak-base, max peak duration 1.2 min, and the working mode set at threshold/ slope. A total of 1.2 mg of the target metabolite was obtained for NMR and high-resolution MS analysis. All solvents were HPLC grade from Fisher Scientific, Canada , and the water was from Barnstead NANO-PURE (Thermo Scientific).

The enriched P2 metabolite isolated from RL6058 flag leaves was analyzed using a Bruker MicroTOF-Q mass analyzer attached to an HPLC system (Agilent 1200 Series) equipped with a DAD detector. The sample (10 μL) was analyzed using a 3.5 micron-pore size ZORBAX SB-C18 column ( 2.1 mm ID � 150 mm ; Agilent) at 25
�
C . The mobile phase consisted of a gradient of acetonitrile and 10 mM ammonium acetate in water (10% acetonitrile for 2 min; increased to 40% over 13 min; held at 40% for 1 min; decreased to 10% over 2 min and held at 10% for 7 min) at a flow rate of 0.25 mL/min. UV detection was scanning across 200–400 nm . For mass analysis, positive electrospray ionization mode (ES þ ) was used. Mass range was selected from 100 to 1400 Da. The MS was operated in full scan and auto-MS/MS modes using Argon for CID (collision-induced dissociation) to form product ions. Mass was calibrated using ESI-Low concentration Tuning Mix (Agilent). Presumed chemical formulae, error (ppm) and mSigma were calculated using the SmartFormula calculator (Bruker). Biliverdin ( C 33 H 35 N 4 O 5 , [M þ H]
þ m/ z
583.2555 (theoretical 583.2551), error - 0.6 ppm, mSigma 27.3) was used as MS (ESI þ ) reference material to verify the performance of mass calibration.

P2 sample ( 0.8 mg ) was dissolved in 0.6 mL CD 3 OD (Cambridge Isotope Labs, Tewkesbury, MA) in a 5 mm NMR tube. Spectra were collected using a Bruker 700 MHz spectrometer equipped with a 5 mm TCI cryoprobe operating at a 1 H frequency of 700.15 MHz and a 13 C frequency of 176.05 MHz. Sample temperature was held at 293.2K. Experiments included:1D- 1 H; 1D- 13 C ; 1D- 13 C NOE suppressed; 2D- 1 H COSY; 2D- 1 H TOCSY 120 ms contact time; 2D- 1 H NOESY; 2D- 1 H/ 13 C multiplicity edited HSQC; 2D- 1 H/ 13 C HMBC 60 ms mixing time; 2D- 1 H/ 13 C HMBC 90 ms mixing time. NMR data acquisition and processing of 1 H and 13 C spectra was performed using Bruker Topspin v.3.2 (Bruker Ltd., Milton, ON, Canada ). 2D spectra were acquired into 1K complex points in F2 and 256 complex points in F1. Spectra were then apodized with a π/2 shifted sine squared function and Fourier transformed into 1024 real points in F2 and 1024 real linear predicted points in F1. All spectra were phased to pure absorption mode except for the HMBC spectra which were presented in magnitude mode. All spectra were referenced to the residual CD 2 H resonance of deuterated methanol solvent at 3.31 ppm 1 H and 49.0 ppm 13 C . Proposed structure representation and simulation of 1D spectra was done using ACD/Chem-Sketch (ACD/Labs) and MestReNova (Mestrelab Research S.L.).

The effect of the metabolites on urediniospore germination was evaluated using
Puccinia triticina
isolate 12-3 MBDS ( McCallum et al., 2019 ) and
Puccinia striiformis
f. sp.
tritici
isolate W057 race C-PST-5 ( Brar and Kutcher, 2016 ; Brar et al., 2018 ). Approximately 400 μL of 2% water-based agar solution was aliquoted onto a thick microscope slide with a concave well and flattened using a cover slip. Once polymerized, the cover slip was removed and approximately 40–50 μL of a prepared CFG solution (working solution 0.2 mg /mL CFG in 1% methanol with water; derived from dilution of a 10 mg /mL stock solution of CFG prepared in 50% methanol with water) was aliquoted on top of the agar. Urediniospores were applied by placing a sieve over the slide and brushing the urediniospores into the sieve. The microscope slide was then placed on top of a wet filter paper in a Petri plate to maintain humidity and covered with a lid with a filter paper saturated with nonanol solution (1.56 μL solution nonanol was added to 1 mL acetone with 19 mL water) adhering to the inner surface. This was repeated four times for each condition including 0.2 mg /mL CFG , 1% methanol control, and water, ending with plates being left to incubate at room temperature, or in the case of
P. striiformis
at 10
�
C , under normal light conditions. Slides were photographed under the microscope at prescribed time points up to 24 h, and urediniospore germination and germ tube elongation were evaluated by visual inspection of the images.

1-O- p -coumaroyl-3-O-feruloylglycerol (CFG; Cat # SL-1122) and feruloyl glycerol (FG; Cat # SL-1121) were synthesized by SynInnova Laboratories Inc. Ferulic acid (FA) and coumaric acid (CA) were purchased from Sigma. The effects of the metabolites on the hyphal growth of
F. graminearum
strain GZ3639 ( Procter et al., 1995 ) were tested on potato dextrose agar (PDA) plates. Briefly, metabolites dissolved in DMSO were spread on PDA plates (50 μL of metabolite solution spread on 5 mL solidified PDA on a 60 mm Petri plate) to obtain a final metabolite concentration of 4 mM. Equal volume of DMSO was spread onto control plate. The assay was performed with four replicates. The plates were incubated for an hour to let the metabolites absorb into the media. A small plug of
F. graminearum GZ
3639 from a freshly grown plate was placed at the center of each plate and the plates were incubated under constant light at 27
�
C for three days. The diameter of fungal colonies in each plate was measured and recorded each day after inoculation for up to 3 d.

Statistical analyses of the data in this study were performed using R (https://www.r-project.org/). One-way and multifactor ANOVA was conducted using the linear model function ‘lm’. Multiple comparisons were performed using the ‘LSD.test’ function in the R library ‘agricolae’. The Non-parameter statistical method, Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test (‘krustal.test’ function in R), was also used to examine statistical significance between two or more treatments.
The authors declare no competing interests.
This manuscript represents National Research Council of Canada Communication NRCC# 56461.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112456.
This work was funded by the National Research Council of Canada - Wheat Flagship, as part of the Canadian Wheat Alliance.
